title: Finding the Sixth Object
learning_objectives: Extend the counting sequence from five to ten
Understand that each number represents a quantity one greater than the last

variants.explanation:
Remember how we confidently counted to five? Let's start there. I have five cheerful red apples on the table.

*places 5 red objects*
One, two, three, four, five.

Now, watch carefully. I am going to add just ONE more green apple.

*places 1 green object*

If we had five, and we add one more, what do you think the next number in our sequence will be? (Wait for expected answer/confirmation)

It's SIX! Let's count them all together, starting from the beginning: One... two... three... four... five... SIX! That green apple made the whole group bigger by just one. Six means a group of five and one more. Now, letâ€™s keep going all the way to ten: seven, eight, nine, ten. Did you notice how each new number is just the number before it, plus one tiny friend?

title: Count and Compare 6-10
learning_objectives: Practice counting up to ten with one-to-one correspondence
Use number words to compare quantities

variants.explanation:
Let's work together to make sure we've mastered this sequence. I am going to set out two different groups of colorful rings. Look at the first group of rings.

*presents 8 rings*

Can you point to each ring and say the number as you count? (Student is guided to count to 8). That's right, there are eight rings! Now look at the second group of rings.

*presents 6 rings*

How many are in this group? Count them again, slowly, one by one. (Student is guided to count to 6). Six! 

Now, here is the question for your internal 'SelfModel': Which group has more rings, the group of eight, or the group of six? How did you use your counting to figure out which number is larger? We used our counting skills to compare the groups!

title: The Ten-Item Challenge
learning_objectives: Independently count a quantity up to 10

variants.explanation:
You are doing wonderful work! Here is your final challenge to complete all by yourself. I have a pile of shiny coins for you.

*presents 9 coins*

Can you count every single coin, making sure you only touch or point to each one *once*, and then tell me the final number? If you give me the number, and it isn't correct, I will ask you to try again. I trust you to check your own work. Take a deep breath, and ask yourself: 'Did I point to every coin? Did I skip or count any coin twice?' Tell me when you are absolutely sure of the final count.
